GlobalVariables.StudyName: Worksite (well-being, states and immediate antecedents) - template V2025-03
GlobalVariables.StudyDescription: This file contains the metadata, events, and data for REDCap project "Worksite (well-being, states and immediate antecedents) - template V2025-03".
GlobalVariables.ProtocolName: Worksite (well-being, states and immediate antecedents) - template V2025-03

redcap:Surveys.title: Our work site
redcap:Surveys.instructions:
Dear Colleague

As colleagues in our organization, we are contacting you to complete this survey to help the function of our clinic.

Participation will take about 5 minutes. No identifiable information will be collected about you, and the survey is anonymous. The survey is below

There are no personal benefits or risks to participating in this study. Participation is voluntary, and you can stop taking the survey at any time.

If you have any questions, please contact rbadgett@kumc.edu

Thank you for your time,

contact name goes here @kumc.edu
redcap:Surveys.response_limit_custom_text: Thank you for your interest; however, the survey is closed because the maximum number of responses has been reached.

MetaDataVersion.Name: Worksite (well-being, states and immediate antecedents) - template V2025-03

ItemGroupDef.Name: 1. Please answer the following questions about yourself at work over the last 12 months
2. Please answer the following questions about you and your work over the last 12 months
3. About your manager (this section taken directly from Google - feel free to comment or propose drop/add questions) If we use this, we need to verify we are using this for non-profit uses.
4 Would you like more control over your work?

Question.TranslatedText: Survey number

Survey sources (this field is not displayed on the survey)
Section 1. Workforce states NHS Staff Surveys: See 'Core Questionnaire at https://www.nhsstaffsurveys.com/survey-documents/ Engagement questions benchmarks American Psychiatric Association (APA) at https://www.apa.org/topics/workplace Engagement questions benchmarks Thriving Porath and Spreitzer, 2012 (permission required) Leykum, 2011 Proactive FEVS Fuller, 2006 (permission required) General Social Survey (University of Chicago) at https://gss.norc.org/Pages/quality-of-worklife.aspx Work satisfaction benchmarks Section 2. Antecedents AHRQ SOPS - https://www.ahrq.gov/sops/ Various original studies Section3, managers https://rework.withgoogle.com/en/guides/managers-give-feedback-to-managers#have-managers-share-feedback-with-the-team (Terms of usage link)

ItemDef.Name: current_burnout
ItemDef.redcap:SectionHeader: 1. Please answer the following questions about yourself at work over the last 12 months

Question.TranslatedText: Using your own definition of "burnout," please choose one of the answers below.
Please identify things with your workflow or institution that make you feel "burned out" or limit your ability to enjoy your work.
Please identify any protocols, adjustments, or interventions you or your institution has made to decrease your feeling of "burnout" if any.
Question.redcap:FormattedTranslatedText: Please identify any protocols, adjustments, or interventions you or your institution has made to decrease your feeling of "burnout" if any.

Question.TranslatedText: I look forward to going to work.
I am enthusiastic about my job.
Time passes quickly when I am working
On the whole, how satisfied are you with the work you do?
I am constantly looking for ways to do my job better
I recommend my organization as a good place to work

ItemDef.Name: leykum_learning_from_peers
ItemDef.redcap:SectionHeader: 2. Please answer the following questions about you and your work over the last 12 months

Question.TranslatedText: I am frequently taught new things by people I work with.
I get all the important information I need to do my work.
Our work site trains staff when new processes are put into place
Our work site makes sure staff get the on-the-job training they need
My organization has frequent interactions with outside organizations (eg, other hospitals and professional associations) to acquire new knowledge on how to improve care.
In this office, we treat each other with respect.
This office emphasizes teamwork when taking care of patients.
When someone in this office gets really busy, others help out
We are encouraged to come up with ideas for more efficient ways to do our work.
We are involved in making decisions about changes to our work processes.
We are given opportunities to try out solutions to workflow problems.
Staff are encouraged to express alternative viewpoints in this office
We have enough staff to handle our patient load
We have problems with workflow in this office
I am able to deliver the care I aspire to.
My job activities are personally meaningful to me.
Management takes a positive interest in my health and well-being.
Communication between senior management and staff is effective.
How fair is what you earn on your job in comparison to others doing the same type of work you do?

ItemDef.Name: google_manager_recommend
ItemDef.redcap:SectionHeader: 3. About your manager (this section taken directly from Google - feel free to comment or propose drop/add questions) If we use this, we need to verify we are using this for non-profit uses.

Question.TranslatedText: I would recommend my manager to others.
My manager assigns stretch opportunities to help me develop in my career.
My manager communicates clear goals for our team
My manager gives me actionable feedback on a regular basis
My manager provides the autonomy I need to do my job (i.e., does not "micro-manage" by getting involved in details that should be handled at other levels)
My manager consistently shows consideration for me as a person
My manager keeps the team focused on priorities, even when it's difficult (e.g., declining or deprioritizing other projects)
My manager regularly shares relevant information from their manager and senior leadership
My manager has had a meaningful discussion with me about my career development in the past six months
My manager has the technical expertise (e.g., technical judgment in Tech, selling in Sales, accounting in Finance) required to effectively manage me
The actions of my manager show they value the perspective I bring to the team, even if it is different from their own
My manager makes tough decisions effectively (e.g., decisions involving multiple teams, competing priorities)
My manager effectively collaborates across boundaries (e.g., team, organizational)
What would you recommend your manager keep doing?
What would you have your manager change?

ItemDef.Name: authorities
ItemDef.redcap:SectionHeader: 4 Would you like more control over your work?

Question.TranslatedText:
What decision-making authority, if you were allowed to have, would make your job easier?
This may be day-to-day decisions, or decisions about changes to our workflows
What information will you need, perhaps ongoing, to make these decisions well?

ItemDef.Name: gender
ItemDef.redcap:FieldNote: We are asking this question because prior studies suggest burnout occurs more frequently in the female workforce.

Question.TranslatedText: What gender do you identify with?
Do you have face-to-face contact with patients as part of your job?
Are you a healthcare practitioner (physician, PA, NP)?
At which site are you employed?
Are you
If you answered 'other' above, please name.
Question.redcap:FormattedTranslatedText: If you answered 'other' above, please name.

Question.TranslatedText: Complete?

Decode.TranslatedText: I enjoy my work. I have no symptoms of burnout.
I am under stress, and don't always have as much energy as I did, but I don't feel burned out.
I am definitely burnt out and have one or more symptoms of burnout, e.g., emotional exhaustion.
The symptoms of burnout that I am experiencing won't go away. I think about work frustrations a lot.
I feel completely burned out. I am at the point where I may need to seek help.
About as much as you deserve
CHC Internal Medicine (residency or faculty clinic)
Resident or fellow physician in training
